description.text:
*** Hey, if you like this one, fine. But take a look at Version 2.0 over chya... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1687448

I liked the holder I remixed but for a couple of things... it required extra hardware (beyond the bearings) and they were multi-piece.

So I modified the bearing axles to have a mushroomed head and a split down the middle so that a bearing could be popped on and retained without additional hardware to hold them in place.

I also modified the frame mount for the 20mm aluminum frame. I stuck a tiny bulge in the arms that slip over the frame rail that grab on to the center channel. They snap beautifully into place and provide enough resistance not to slide around but can be coaxed to adjust to width.

Result... 2 of these and 4 608 skateboard bearings gets you a completely width-adjustable filament roller that sits on top of your aluminum-extrusion-frame printer of choice.

NOTE: I realized, after I jacked my Z all the way to the top, that the X carriage will interfere with these mounts. No problem unless you're printing something more than 180-190mm in height, or however tall yours is until interference occurs. Check it.

title: Fan shroud, dual cooling fan mounts, + ring LED mount for E3D v6 hotend.

description.text:
Integrated hotend fan shroud, dual part cooling fan mounts, and part light (ring LED) mount for E3D v6 hotend. This will fit under a standard Kossel delta end-effector mount and any other printer that can take the E3D v6 hotend with fan shroud attached.

Print (2) fan director ducts and (1) each of the LED mount and shroud.

Requires a separate output (FET) for part cooling. My LED is wired to another FET output and turns on 100% when I put the printer in RUN mode. I have my E3D fan turn on with printer power so it is always cooling hotend.

Uses (hardware)
(1) uxcell® 80mm 24 SMD LED Car Angle Eye Halo Ring Light
(2) generic 30mm x 30mm x 10mm fans (12V) for part cooling
(1) E3D 30mm x 30mm x 10mm fan (or generic if no fan supplied with E3D v6)
(6-12) 3mm shcs bolts x 12mm long to attach fans to mounts (2 per fan is sufficient for me)
(2) 3mm flat-head bolts x 8mm (or shorter) long to attach cooling ducts to LED mount
(2) 3mm shcs bolts x 12mm long to attach cooling ducts to hotend shroud.
(1) small zip tie if necessary to keep shroud tight to hotend. (I haven't used it yet, but I included it in the design just in case)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed with PET-G. You could also probably use ABS. I would not suggest PLA as there is potential for excessive heat on some of the components.

The LED ring mount has a hole for the LED wires to stick through. Make sure this lines up well before pushing down too hard on the LED into the mount. The LED may snap into place quite nicely. If you want to, you could add some adhesive to ensure a better hold. I put a little hot glue on the ring tabs to hold them into the mount.

I referenced a couple of other designs on Thingiverse, but didn't see a totally integrated design I liked so I started from scratch in AutoCAD and sculpted the fan shroud based on the E3D design, added the side mounts, sculpted the cooling ducts, and measured out the LED mount for a firm fit.

comments.author: ProtomakerSprint

comments.text: In machinekit (the control software for my beaglebone black control board) I have the ability to control the brightness by sending the percentage of "on". So, if I turn on the light with setting of "50" the light is only half brightness, for example. You could experiment and see if you have the ability to set a brightness option in your control software. Some software controls allow for 0=off, 1=on, and any decimal number between 0 and 1 to be a percentage of full scale. Otherwise, you could add a variable resistor inline with the voltage feed to the light and dial the brightness to your liking.

description.text:
This was made at George Mason University for Math493: Mathematics Through 3D Printing, taught by Dr. Evelyn Sander.

Gives the double integral approximation for the function f(x,y) = 2*e^(-x^2-y^2), the Gaussian curve in 3 dimensions, using 100, 225, and 400 rectangular prisms, respectively on the interval [-2,2.5]x[-2,2]. The Mathematica code used to generate these models was based on Raouf Boules', Geoff Goodson's, Ohoe Kim's and Mike O'Leary's Calculus III Lab at Towson University, found here: http://www2.stetson.edu/~wmiles/coursedocs/Fall_05/MS_203/calc3labs/Calculus%20III%20-%20Lab%209.htm.

The integral approximator (code provided below) takes a function f on an interval [a1,b1]x[a2,b2] with n discretization points in both the x and y directions, therefore approximating the area under the function with n^2 rectangular prisms (cuboids in Mathematica). Just like in the 1-dimensional integral approximation methods, deltaX = (b1-a1)/n and deltaY = (b2-a2)/n. The x and y coordinates of the jth and kth rectangle are thus given by x_j = a1+deltaXj and y_k = a2+deltaYk.

In Mathematica, Cuboid[{lower corner (x,y,z), upper corner (x,y,z)]. Here the lower corner is given by (x_j, yk, 0), and the upper corner (x(j+1), y_(k+1), f(x_j, y_k)).

Suggestions: try playing around with the function, and changing the number of rectangles used.

Mathematica code:

RD[f, {a1, b1}, {a2, b2}, n] :=
Show[Table[
Graphics3D[Cuboid[{a1 + (b1 - a1)/nj, a2 + (b2 - a2)/nk, 0},
{a1 + (b1 - a1)/n(j + 1), a2 + (b2 - a2)/n(k + 1),
f[a1 + (b1 - a1)/nj, a2 + (b2 - a2)/nk]}]], {j, 0, n - 1}, {k,
0, n - 1}]]
Clear[f, x, y]
f[x, y] := 2*Exp[-x^2 - y^2]
print1 = RD[f, {-2, 2.5}, {-2, 2}, 10]
Export["filename.stl",print1]

For this model the fpv equipment is:
-Coaxial wire as dipole antenna
-Microcamera 600tv 3gr
-Trasmitter TX5823
-Polulu voltage regulator or another 150mah lipo for clean/separate power supply

All the electronic and motor are easy to access.
The motor holders are flexible so you can attach motors 7-6mm size.
For the test model the flight controller used is microwii with dms2 receiver on board but a wide variety on flight controllers can be mounted.

UPDATE V5:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1504643

Full tutorial here:
http://eduardochamorro.github.io/beansreels/indextutorials.html

title: HTC Vive Lighthouse Adapters for Plaster/Drywall

description.text:
** Disclaimer; I take no responsibility for any damage to you, your house, your HTC Vive, lighthouses and/or associated equipment through use of this plate.

FILES:

There are two different versions included, you will need 1 per lighthouse;

  • vlh_phsingle.stl - Hanger for single picture hooks
  • vlh_phdual.stl - Hanger for dual picture hooks (*preferable for situations where lighthouse needs to angle to left/right extremes)
DESCRIPTION:

A bracket which can be hung on the wall using simple picture hooks/hangers from your local supermarket or hardware store. This is a good solution to minimise damage to your wall. The adapter supports hangars and hooks up to 5.5mm wide.

Click for hangers I used
INSTALLATION:
  1. Attach the Vive lighthouse bracket to the flat side of the plate, you can use your own mounting hardware (or cut down the screws included with the lighthouse bracket).
  2. Connect power cable to lighthouse
  3. Install on the wall using picture hook.
  4. Aim lighthouse as required, and your set.
NOTE: I have mounted both my lighthouses using these brackets, they are solid and safe. They will not fall off the wall like adhesive tapes and other 'sticky' solutions. If you have pictures hanging on the wall, you should be able to take them down and hang your lighthouses there instead.

title: Gantry for use with sc8luu and sk8 + Fake Nema 17 motor idler pulley holder

description.text:
From the information i got in various places in the internet, sc8luu and lm8uu bearings are great but only if they are installed straight. If they are not, they are going to stutter and can even spit a few balls here and there(yeah this happened to me as well and is mostly the reason for this design).  
So, after buying the parts i needed to find a way to use them... This is my own design, having the gantry as a single piece like that is the only way i know to prevent wobbling, and whatnot. Using machined parts is not cheap but i needed to anyway since i'm stuck with a few high speed ball screws i want to use.  
I'm planning to have these made in a few month. The gantry need to be machined from a thick piece of aluminium (6mm should be enough). The ems file is for emachineshop.com's custom software.   
Your going to need shoulder screws if you use the gantry design as is. Look for 6mm shoulder screws with M5 threads. I used this design because the V-Slot from OpenBuilds are for M5 screws and i was going to need to order some anyway. I might change my design at some point since those screws are not cheap.  
If you ever want to have the gantry made, contact me so we can save with a group buy. Most of the cost is usually the initial setup so dont be shy, show yourself. Msg me in private for that.  
I'm not sure about the Pulley holder disguised as a nema 17 motor but i thought the idea would be cool, and it gives you the option of easily installing a second motor if you ever want to.  
Update: The aluminium piece as been aligned every hole as been dialed in manually, so everything is squared. I modified it to use a steel motor mount, it did not feel right to use a pla mount when everything else would've been aluminium. i'm leaving the fake nema motor pulley holder there, mostly because i think its a cool idea, and i got a few thick 1.5" wide washers i can probably fit inside. With a bit of epoxy it should be strong enough to witstand anything. i'm probably going to design a cover to hide the hole. I still to design the carriage.

This project of a tricopter was derived from an existing one called Brocopter. I advise you to have a look at this drone before. You can find all the instructions, CAD files and videos of the original at this link : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:413639
So at the beginning, my idea was to build a drone as cheap as possible and which could be easy to build and then to carry. That’s why I decided to make this foldable version of a drone. But in order to save some money, I’ve made some modifications which are the following ones :

  • First, I replaced the carbon plates by wooden plates. That’s cheaper and can be directly cut with a lasercut machine.
  • I updated the CAD models of the motor’supports.
  • I changed the ESC case (because I wanted to fit my cheaper ESC in this drone)
    The result is a drone which is a bit heavier but it remains solid and cheaper.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used PLA.
Can be done in 0.2mm except for the yaw horn.

Motor mounts modifications

Most of the 3D printed parts are the same as the ones used in the original brocopter drone. But I found that the feet on motor mounts are a bit fragile to support the shock of a landing. Furthermore, the shape is a bit tricky to print. So these mounts are retrofitted in the way to rigidify the assembly and to print it easily.

Motor mounts updates Servo mount modification

I modified the servo mount too for fitting an emax es08d servo in it.

New ESC case

And finally, I completely changed the ESC case which, in the original drone, is a case designed for ESC that have specific dimensions. As I wanted to use cheaper ESC (bigger), I had to design a new case and contrary to the original project, this case is put in the front of the frame. (This space is occupied by a FPV camera in the original drone but you can still add a camera to this drone directly on the top of the top frame).

description.text:
Geodesic sphere for OpenSCAD, intended to be a drop-in replacement for sphere() for those cases when you want uniformly spaced facets that don't bunch up at the poles.

Respects parameters "r" or "d" just like built-in sphere(), and also respects $fa, $fs, and $fn to produce approximately comparable facet sizes.

author: guldokat

description.text:
If you'd like to see more, watch this video: https://youtu.be/T2Ly_pLtiOQ

This is a 3D printed Clank model from the video game and movie Ratchet & Clank. At the scale given, it'll end up being about 6 inches tall. I created this model in Fusion 360 and printed it on my Robo 3D R1 printer using Hatchbox White PLA.

Post Processing:
Step 1: Assemble and glue the pieces together using super glue.
Step 2: Prime the model with plastic primer.
Step 3: Paint the metallic finish on him, we used Krylon Hammered Metal spray paint through an airbrush.
Step 4: Paint the details. We used water based acrylic paints with a paint brush to get the dark gray, green, and red areas painted.

Something to keep in mind while assembling is his position. Try to position his arms and legs so that he'll stand on his own and not fall over.

Print Settings:
Layer Height: 0.3mm (0.1mm for arms)
Infill: 20%
Supports/Raft: None

author: jahojung

description.text:
A housing for the common 150W DC booster available on ebay and everywhere else. I use the booster to supply the stepper drivers with 24V while using a 12V PSU.

The box offers a bend protection and access to the potentiometer.

You'll need 4x 10mm M3 screws and nuts.

comments.text:
Hi,
I like your design. I have the similar printer from Geeetech, and I am thinking of modifying the controller board to use 24V for stepper drivers. I have seen your post on Geeetech forum, but I am not sure whether this step is really beneficial or not. Have you noticed some difference when you used 24V to power your stepper drivers? Does it worth it to touch the controller board?
comments.author: BigSteve

comments.text: It is highly beneficial if you use the TMC2100 drivers (http://www.watterott.com/de/SilentStepStick). These are silent only if supplied with at least 20V (https://github.com/watterott/SilentStepStick/blob/master/docu/FAQ.md). The [email protected] are much more silent than the a4998 or drv8825. Using 24V for the latter two drivers is not beneficial.
comments.author: BigSteve

comments.text: I am currently using DRV8825 drivers. I thought, applying 24V to stepper drivers I could improve stepper performance. In this case, I won't touch the control board and I let everything on 12V. I am satisfied with DRV8825 till now, they are more silent than a4998 and they work well. TMC2100 might be much better but I do not really need so silent printer.
comments.author: lukie80

comments.text:
You're welcome. I chose to mod my board with the step-up-converter, because my heat-bed and hot-end are made for 12V.
With respect to the drv8825 drivers: I used them too. I noticed a quality issue at low speeds (translated from German): https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=de&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fforums.reprap.org%2Fread.php%3F249%2C388795%2C629757%23msg-629757
So the solution was a "decay hack" (http://www.morgan3dp.com/stepstuck-revisited-drv8825/). However, with this hack the drv8825 are twittering loudly around 10kHz which is quite annoying.
comments.author: BigSteve

comments.text:
Hi,
so I gave a try to silentstepstick TMC2100 driver. First I tried the default stelthChop mode. It was very silent however I was loosing steps during print and the driver was getting very very hot. Then I switched to the spreadCycle mode. The printer is now running fine and the driver does not get so hot, but there is a strong high pitch noise coming from the stepper motor. I tried different voltages from 12V to 30V and nothing really changed. It might be even louder than the DRV8825 in the mixed decay mode.
comments.author: lukie80

comments.text: Hello
comments.author: BigSteve

comments.text: Yes, I double-checked everything. The driver is correctly set to spreadCycle mode. I removed the CFG1 pin and soldered a wire to connect it to GND. Then I also interconnected a small bridge on driver board to connect the chip pin to the board pin. By default, all CFG bridges are open on my driver board (so CFG0, CFG2-5 are open). I will try to tune the driver with CFG0, CFG4 and CFG5 to reduce the noise.
comments.author: lukie80

comments.text: Yes, luckily the GT2560 follows the RAMPS schematic which also has a pull-down resistor. However, maybe the pull-down is not enough and I'm running in StealthChop from the beginning?
comments.author: BigSteve

comments.text: The100k pull-down resistor is sufficient and it allows to switch the driver to SpreadCycle mode. I tested it and it works.
comments.author: lukie80

comments.text: So with CFG1=GND, CFG2=open and 24V yous TMCs are silent now. Why were they noisy in the first place?
comments.author: BigSteve

comments.text: The Chinese TMC2100 driver has a different configuration of bridges than the driver by Waterott. Changing this configuration of bridges to the same as by Waterott the driver got more silent. So the Chinese TMC2100 are not configured or in other words, the bridge configuration is on the buyer. It was discussed also here in this thread: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?249,682486,683917#msg-683917
comments.author: lukie80

comments.text: You're welcome. Wow. I didn't expect that the Chinese drivers had a different configuration. Thanks for the Info.
comments.author: BigSteve

comments.text:
Yes, I have heard about some issue with DRV8825 drivers: http://cabristor.blogspot.cz/2015/02/drv8825-missing-steps.html. I haven't really noticed this problem at my printer but unfortunately I haven't had other drivers so I can not compare.
I check the original forum thread, I understand German.

comments.text: Nice, just what I needed. Thank you.

title: front fan mount + light ring holder. for prusa x carriage.

description.text:
I've seen the light mounts and the fan mounts and ive seen the fan mount integrated into a carriage. But I didn't want to reprint a carriage and figured I could do both at once. I FITS well, but I used a lot of hot glue to keep it in place. A key feature of this is that it vents the fan upward to the insulator of the hot end, the airflow doesn't hit the heating block. I use this most excellent hot end: http://www.hotends.com/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=70 and the fan helps to keep the pla cool until the last cm and the light ring:
http://www.dealextreme.com/p/2-25w-15-led-5050-smd-led-car-angel-eye-light-ring-58430
line it up so the angle is flush. glue in place. put the fan on, glue around the edges, the fan adds rigidity. put the light ring on.

title: Migbot Electron Prusa i3 Z-axle Stabilising Cap

description.text: This is a cap designed to fit onto the end of the threaded Z-axes on a Migbot/Electron/Mendel Prusa i3 which helps prevent Z-axis wobble on printouts. You need to printout two caps for it to work.

comments.text: This is not a good idea. The holes where the z axis threaded rods go through are over sized for a reason. A rod that is not perfectly straight, as many are not, needs to be free to wobble otherwise the bearing on the smooth rod will bind as the threaded rod will apply undesirable force to the bearing. A bit of threaded rod wobble does not matter as it is the smooth rods and bearings that stabilise the Z axis.
comments.author: Geoffs

comments.text: What size rod does this fit?
comments.author: Achoo01

I only tested this with a Gopro Hero 3 Silver. Make sure you use a camera with the same size.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:753477

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=753477

Using the following options:

text = Xls
web = 0
spacing = 1
size = 20
font = Aldrich
direction = ltr
extrude = 5

I wanted a filament spool holder that:
  • fits every spool
  • allows quick and easy spool changes without tools
  • holds the spool tight while maintaining low friction
    • So I borrowed the design of the double countersunk spoolholder with ballbearings, added a large thumbwheel and - to make it even easier to use - I combined the wheel and the front spool insert into a single part. To achieve this I designed the thumbwheel to hold a long ( 30mm ) M6 nut and made the two front bearings wider ( 13 mm inner diameter ) so they can run on the center cylinder of the thumb wheel instead of the threaded rod directly. Now you can take off the combined front part with one hand only and also fastening or releasing the spool is a lot easier. Due to the momentum of the big wheel you can give it a good turn and it will keep turning all the way in or out. A locking nut or wrench is not required. Hand tightening the wheel is enough. Thanks to the low friction of the ball bearings the screw won't loosen itself.

BOM:
  • M6 threaded rod ( if your printer doesn't have one attached already )
  • M6 long nut ( 30 mm, SW 10 )
  • 2 x ball bearing 19-13-4 mm
  • 2 x ball bearing 19-6-6 mm
  • Printed parts 1-3
    • Assembly:
    Take part 2 ( the thumbwheel ) and insert the M6 long nut.
    Take one 13er bearing and push it onto the wheel's center cylinder.
    You might have to use a file on the cylinder to make it fit because in order to slice and print without problems I made the cylinder slightly wider than 13mm. Then push part 1 onto the bearing. Finally push in the second bearing. You might have to use a small hammer because it is supposed to be a tight fit. If it won't fit with a gentle strike of the hammer then you can try to adjust the clearance variable in the OpenSCAD file. It is adjusted to my print settings which are: PLA, 0.5 nozzle, 0.25 layer height.

print_settings.Notes:: Just got my first spool of TPU and it makes for some really nice, flexible lens caps.

description.text: Anyone that has an Eachine 250 quad racer has probably had the same problem as I have trying to pry the lens cap off. The way the lens is flush mounted makes it a challenge. Then what do you do with it once you get it off. I usually put the cap down somewhere and then can't remember where I put it. Here's a solution that I came up with for mine. This lens cap has a handle that you can grab to pull it off and put it back on and it also has a hole in it for a string or tie wrap to secure it to the quad frame. I print mine up in a bright color so you always know if the lens cap is on or not. The handle can also be printed by itself and glued to the existing lens cap for the same effect. Anyway, simple fix. I hope you find it useful.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Workbench

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

60-100%

Notes:

I printed the lens cap in PLA, but it should work equally well with ABS. The handle can be glued to the lens cap with super glue. Due to differences in 3D printer settings the fit may be slightly tight. A small file or sandpaper on the inside ring of the cap can fix that.

Just got my first spool of TPU and it makes for some really nice, flexible lens caps.

description.text:
Tools to help testing multicopter components.
These parts allow building a single motor/propeller support (monocopter) and an one axis, two arms, two motors/propellers (bicopter) setup.
Both mounts can be fixed by a Tetrapack Brick package, using the provided dedicated base.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.4

Infill:

.25

Notes:

All parts are very easy to print.

To build a single motor/propeller support (monocopter), you'll need:

  • 1x mcopter_head_mono.stl
  • 2x* mcopter_tetrapack.stl
  • 2x mcopter_tetrapack_cross.stl

To biild an one axis, two arms, two motors/propellers (bicopter) setup, you'll need:

  • 1x mcopter_bi_head.stl
  • 1x mcopter_bi_support.stl
  • 1x mcopter_bi_top.stl
  • 1x Cylinder axis, not included.
  • 2x Multicopter arms, not include.
  • 2x mcopter_tetrapack.stl
  • 2x mcopter_tetrapack_cross.stl
Some parts have support material already included. Please remove it after printing.

This is a Star topper for a desktop christmas tree. A 0.23" diameter hole was drilled in the back of the star on center to allow for a standard christmas light to mount to it. The body of the star is hollow which allows for the light to illuminate the star with whatever color is used. 
This star was made using a 3d printer which could add filler material. The main light hole and two drain holes were added in order for the filler material to dissolve when immersed in its solution.

comments.text: Well kinda prints okay.   What settings did you use?  mine dropped a lot of filiment inside since there's no structure to manage the bridges.   It printed out workable, but a little more work internally would make it much more reprap friendly.
comments.author: PharaohABQ

comments.text: What a nice print. It fit our small tree perfectly. A small hole drilled in the back accepted a light and it looks fantastic. Merry Christmas everyone.
comments.author: jimcook

title: RunCam2 Mount for QAV210
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a RunCam2 camera mount for the QAV210 frame. It has a few overhangs, but prints okay if you print it with the lens protector down. There are four versions, each with a different angle - 25, 30, 35, and 40 degrees. While the camera hangs out over the front of the frame, your FPS camera should not see it in the view as long as the angle is greater than or equal to the mount. The photos were from a test print that didn't match the curve in the front of the frame perfectly, but the rest worked very well. The uploaded STL's are correct. It was printed in ABS.

Working on a Kawasaki ninja motorcycle I needed to adjust the carb enrichment screw. If you are familiar with them the screw is underneath the carb. So you cant see how many turns you have made. This is a simple pointer to put on a flat head driver bit so you have some reference to what you have done. This item is not very complex but what i am trying to show is just how having a printer can make things to do everyday jobs much easier.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with supports and at least 3 shells / >1mm to make the pegboard prongs strong enough.

description.text:
My printing operation is in my basement where the wifi signal isn't the best, so I bought one of these to improve my reception (it seems to work quite well!)

This fits a TL-WN722N High - gain wifi antenna (link above), and mounts it to a pegboard with 1" hole spacing. The print in the pictures is a pretty snug fit for the adapter, which is fine because I can connect/disconnect the usb from the adapter with one hand if needed.

You'll need to print this with supports for the prongs. See print settings below.

Thanks to twobraids, I used his prong design for this adapter bracket.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Print with supports and at least 3 shells / >1mm to make the pegboard prongs strong enough.

description.text:
I keep losing my memory cards, so when I had some extra time on a laser machine I decided to do something about it.

I had some 2mm cardboard laying around so I designed a pretty simple drawer-like system to protect the cards between a couple of cardboard sheets.

The whole layout is really small, you can actually cut two holders from a single A4 sheet. You can also personalize it by engraving your own designs.

more on www.rogzam.com

description.text:
This is a smaller version of my stove stand :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:814321
Designed to be use on the top of a tripod. After a photography day, why not use this bulky piece of equipement as a kitchen stand ?

DON'T USE IT ON A HIGH OR INSTABLE TRIPOD !
I use a sirui sirui t-025x carbon.

  • Compatible with most gas canisters (109mm and 90mm).
  • Foldable, easy to pack

Print 3x feet.stl and 1x center.stl
You will need 3 M3x15 screw (M3x12 works fine too).
Screws goes head up, tighten as needed.

The center part is designed to receive an M5 press fit brass insert (use a soldering iron or heat it to mount it).
My tripods have arca-swiss heads so I used walter's plate:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1096601
Add an M5x16 counter sunk hex screw and you're good to go

BQ hephestos 2

No

No

0.2-0.3

20-100%

comments.text: I printed this last night from orange TPU and it came out so nice.  It was my first time printing with TPU had to slow the machine down to 30mm/sec 220degrees and bed set to 60.  After 4 hours it said 2% complete so I was anticipating about 100hours of printing, but when I woke this morning it was complete after just 10 hours and fits perfectly.   I always had issues with the volume buttons on the S6 now this case makes it supper easy.  Thanks again.

Wall mount Makerbot filament support. When using external filament with Makerbot.

OpenForge 2.0

This is the first set in the external wall cut-stone series for OpenForge. A lot has changed with how I do walls that don't sit on the base, and I've changed the name from "edge" to "external" wall in part to differentiate them. Read below and I'll explain.

If you don't want to use the new attachable base, full tiles with bases attached are also uploaded with the name *.full_base.stl

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Instructions

For assembly instructions, painting videos and other extra information, see the instructions on the cut-stone wall.

As I add new tiles to this set, I'll link back here, and continue to grow the instructions on how to best use the external wall tiles. Historically, with the edge wall tiles, the wall was the same thickness as the normal tiles. This made edge tiles kind of a pain to use, as there was a fairly odd gap that sat between tiles when you tried to line them up. With the external wall tiles, the wall is now 12.5mm, which is exactly half the width of a tile square. This size makes reasoning about external wall tiles much easier, and has the benefit of making them completely compatible with tiles made using HirstArts molds.

First and foremost, what this means is if you place two of the external walls back to back, they take up exactly one square of space.

Second, this eliminates the need for edge buffers, and we can have half widths of floor, which is much easier to use, and frankly looks a lot better.

As this new set gets going, I'm going to release half floor tiles, as well as a small set of adapters that make working with the external wall tiles substantially easier. As those get added, I'll document here how to best use these parts.

Two external walls back to back now line up with the grid (Better photo forthcoming) Changelog
  • 5/30/2016 - Added 0.5 increments of walls for use in assembling wall pieces using parts as per the cut-stone external door

The Story

This was the addition that was made in order to go on top of (of all things) an oscillating sprinkler. We printed off a male sprinkler head adapter and attached it to the bottom of this print, then screwed the whole thing into the hose end of an old recycled oscillating sprinkler. A little bit of metallic spray-paint later and the whole things was a go.

Basically I dropped the Medallion file into Tinkercad and oriented over the preformed shapes until I got something I liked.

The negative relief used the text-creator add-on and can be changed easily from the Tinkercad files.

I needed a tool holder to (perfectly) create hobbed bolts to use in my new bowden extruder.
Naturally I made it as customizable.

title: Insignia Bluetooth Behind The Head cushion retainer ring

description.text:
This is a replacement part for my NS-BTHDP wireless headset.  This headset has been very useful and comfortable for several years.  They have endured some abuse and finally one of the foam/fabric cushions started falling off.  I broke the retainer ring.  
This thing is an attempt to get more comfortable years out of them as the rest of the unit is still good with great battery life still left.  
If this does not work then I'll have to turn them into a wireless receiver for my boat's head unit.  I'll feed the speaker outputs to the Aux in and probably make a little container for it.  
UPDATE! I've added a second version to facilitate printing without support or raft.  The first one needed it and was creating problems with the fit.  Upon further inspection of the Original there is no need for the extra features.   
A third model to mix things up a bit.  Also to make it easier to twist in to the lock position.

The first version is a close replica of the original and will need support to print.  
The second version is modified slightly and does not need support.  However if printing in ABS, there is some shrinkage that needs to be accounted for, PLA prints fit fine.  
Use 1 or 2 layers and 100% infill.  Its a small part so it will print fast even at 100% infill.
